light_details: Tolerates low light but grows faster in bright, indirect light. Avoid direct sunlight which can scorch leaves.
water_details: Allow soil to dry completely between waterings. Very drought tolerant due to rhizomes that store water.
humidity_details: Tolerates dry air well. Average household humidity (30-50%) is perfect.
soil_details: Use cactus/succulent mix or add perlite to regular potting soil for drainage.
fertilizer_details: Diluted liquid fertilizer spring through summer. No feeding in winter.
toxicity: Toxic to pets and humans if ingested. Contains calcium oxalate crystals.
propagation_details: Can propagate from single leaflets in water or soil. Division of rhizomes when repotting.
common_problems: Yellow leaves (overwatering), brown tips (underwatering or fluoride in water)
pruning: Minimal - remove yellow or damaged leaves at base
special_features: Air purifying, extremely low maintenance, architectural form
trivia: ZZ plants can survive months without water. Popular in offices due to low light tolerance.

light_details: Thrives in bright, indirect light. Can tolerate some morning sun. Low light slows growth and reduces fenestrations.
water_details: Water when top 2 inches of soil are dry. Likes consistent moisture but not waterlogged.
humidity_details: Prefers 60%+ humidity. Mist regularly or use humidity tray. Brown edges indicate low humidity.
soil_details: Peat-based mix with perlite and bark. Slightly acidic pH preferred.
fertilizer_details: Balanced liquid fertilizer spring through summer. Reduce to monthly in fall.
toxicity: Toxic to pets and humans. Contains insoluble calcium oxalates.
propagation_details: Cut below node with aerial root. Root in water or soil. Very easy to propagate.
common_problems: Brown tips (low humidity), yellow leaves (overwatering), no splits (needs more light/maturity)
pruning: Prune for size control in spring. Can train on moss pole.
repotting: Annually when young, every 2 years when mature
special_features: Iconic split leaves, fast growing, easy to propagate, aerial roots
trivia: Name means 'delicious monster' - fruit is edible when ripe but rare indoors. Leaves develop splits as plant matures.

light_details: Extremely adaptable. Variegation fades in low light. Avoid direct sun.
water_details: Water when top inch is dry. Very forgiving of irregular watering.
humidity_details: Tolerates dry air but appreciates occasional misting.
soil_details: Any well-draining potting soil works. Not picky about soil type.
fertilizer_details: Light feeding with diluted liquid fertilizer. Can survive without fertilizing.
toxicity: Toxic to pets and humans if ingested.
propagation_details: Cut below node, root in water. Roots appear in 1-2 weeks.
common_problems: Brown tips (fluoride in water), yellow leaves (overwatering), pale leaves (too much light)
pruning: Trim to control length and encourage bushiness
special_features: NASA air purifier, trails beautifully, nearly indestructible
trivia: Called 'Devil's Ivy' because it's nearly impossible to kill and stays green even in darkness.

light_details: Prefers bright, indirect light but tolerates various conditions. Direct sun can bleach leaves.
water_details: Keep soil lightly moist. Sensitive to fluoride in tap water - use filtered if possible.
humidity_details: Average household humidity is fine. Brown tips may indicate dry air or fluoride.
soil_details: Standard houseplant mix with good drainage.
fertilizer_details: Diluted liquid fertilizer spring and summer. Reduce in winter.
toxicity: Non-toxic to pets and humans. Safe for households with children and animals.
propagation_details: Root plantlets in water or soil while still attached to mother plant, then cut.
common_problems: Brown tips (fluoride/chlorine in water), pale leaves (needs more light)
pruning: Remove brown tips and old leaves. Cut flower stalks after blooming if desired.
repotting: Every 1-2 years when roots fill pot
special_features: Produces baby plants, air purifying, pet-safe, great for beginners
trivia: NASA study showed it removes 95% of formaldehyde from air in 24 hours.

light_details: Tolerates any light level. Grows faster in bright light but survives in dark corners.
water_details: Water sparingly. Allow soil to dry completely. #1 killer is overwatering.
humidity_details: Thrives in dry air. No misting needed.
soil_details: Fast-draining sandy soil. Add perlite to regular potting mix.
fertilizer_details: Feed once in spring and once in summer with diluted cactus fertilizer.
toxicity: Mildly toxic to pets if ingested. Can cause nausea and vomiting.
propagation_details: Cut leaf into sections, let callus, plant in soil. Or divide rhizomes.
common_problems: Root rot (overwatering), soft leaves (cold damage), brown tips (inconsistent watering)
pruning: Remove damaged leaves at soil level
repotting: Every 3-5 years or when pot breaks from roots
special_features: Releases oxygen at night, extremely drought tolerant, architectural form
trivia: Also called Mother-in-Law's Tongue. One of the best bedroom plants as it produces oxygen at night.

light_details: Thrives in low to medium light. Too much light causes yellow leaves.
water_details: Keep soil consistently moist. Droops dramatically when thirsty - very communicative!
humidity_details: Loves humidity 50%+. Mist regularly or place on pebble tray.
soil_details: Peat-based potting mix that retains some moisture.
fertilizer_details: Balanced liquid fertilizer spring through fall.
toxicity: Toxic to pets and humans. Contains calcium oxalate crystals.
propagation_details: Divide at roots during repotting. Each section needs roots and leaves.
common_problems: Brown tips (low humidity/fluoride), yellow leaves (overwatering), no flowers (needs more light)
pruning: Remove spent flowers and yellow leaves
special_features: White flowers, tells you when thirsty, excellent air purifier
trivia: Not a true lily. NASA clean air study champion - removes ammonia, benzene, formaldehyde.

light_details: Needs bright, indirect light for best growth. Can adapt to medium light.
water_details: Water when top 2 inches dry. Reduce in winter. Leaves drop if too dry or wet.
humidity_details: Appreciates humidity but tolerates normal household levels.
soil_details: Standard potting soil with added perlite for drainage.
fertilizer_details: Diluted liquid fertilizer spring through summer.
toxicity: Toxic sap can irritate skin and is poisonous to pets.
propagation_details: Cut below node, let sap dry, root in water or soil.
common_problems: Leaf drop (overwatering/underwatering), yellowing (needs nutrients), pests (clean leaves regularly)
pruning: Prune for shape in spring. Wear gloves - sap is irritating
special_features: Glossy leaves, air purifying, can grow quite large, burgundy varieties available
trivia: Was original source of rubber before synthetic. Sap is latex - avoid if allergic.

light_details: Loves bright light and some direct sun. Insufficient light causes stretching.
water_details: Water deeply but infrequently. Allow soil to dry completely between waterings.
humidity_details: Prefers dry air. No misting needed - can cause rot.
soil_details: Very well-draining sandy mix. Regular potting soil holds too much moisture.
fertilizer_details: Feed once in spring with diluted succulent fertilizer if desired.
toxicity: Toxic to pets. Can cause vomiting and lethargy.
propagation_details: Remove pups with roots when 3-4 inches tall. Let dry before planting.
common_problems: Brown/soft leaves (overwatering), thin leaves (needs water), pale color (too much sun)
pruning: Remove dead leaves at base. Harvest gel from outer leaves
repotting: Every 2-3 years or when producing many pups
special_features: Medicinal gel, produces pups, drought tolerant, healing properties
trivia: Gel has been used medicinally for 6,000 years. Cleopatra used it in her beauty routine.

light_details: Bright, filtered light. No direct sun which browns fronds.
water_details: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Never let it dry out completely.
humidity_details: Requires 50%+ humidity. Mist daily or use humidifier. Brown tips indicate dry air.
soil_details: Peat-based mix that retains moisture but drains well.
fertilizer_details: Diluted liquid fertilizer spring through fall. Half-strength is best.
toxicity: Non-toxic to pets and humans. Safe for all households.
propagation_details: Divide root ball in spring. Each section needs fronds and roots.
common_problems: Brown tips (low humidity), yellowing (too much sun), leaf drop (too dry)
pruning: Remove dead fronds at base. Trim brown tips
special_features: Classic hanging plant, air purifying, pet-safe, Victorian favorite
trivia: Discovered in 1894 in Boston. NASA rates it as one of the best air-purifying plants.

light_details: Needs lots of bright, indirect light. Turn weekly for even growth.
water_details: Water when top 2 inches dry. Consistent watering schedule is crucial.
humidity_details: Prefers 40-60% humidity. Mist leaves or use humidifier.
soil_details: Quality potting soil with good drainage. Doesn't like to sit in water.
fertilizer_details: Liquid fertilizer with NPK 3-1-2 ratio works best.
toxicity: Toxic to pets and humans. Sap can irritate skin.
propagation_details: Difficult to propagate. Cut below node, root in water with rooting hormone.
common_problems: Brown spots (root rot/bacterial), dropping leaves (shock/inconsistent water), leaning (rotate regularly)
pruning: Prune for shape in spring. Can notch to encourage branching
special_features: Dramatic violin-shaped leaves, Instagram famous, architectural statement
trivia: Became popular after being featured in design magazines. Known as the 'it' plant of the 2010s.

light_details: Medium, indirect light. Direct sun fades leaf patterns. Low light slows growth.
water_details: Keep soil moist but not waterlogged. Use filtered water - sensitive to chemicals.
humidity_details: Needs 50%+ humidity. Group with other plants or use pebble tray.
soil_details: Mix of peat, perlite, and compost. Slightly acidic pH preferred.
fertilizer_details: Diluted liquid fertilizer spring through fall. Reduce in winter.
toxicity: Non-toxic to pets and humans. Safe for all households.
propagation_details: Divide during repotting or root stem cuttings in water.
common_problems: Brown tips (low humidity/fluoride), curling leaves (too dry), fading pattern (too much light)
pruning: Remove yellow leaves. Trim to maintain shape
special_features: Leaves fold at night, striking leaf patterns, pet-safe, movement throughout day
trivia: Leaves fold up at night like praying hands, hence the name. Part of nyctinasty movement.

light_details: Needs bright light with some direct sun. South-facing window ideal.
water_details: Water thoroughly when soil is completely dry. Less in winter.
humidity_details: Prefers dry air. No misting - can cause leaf rot.
soil_details: Fast-draining sandy soil. Add perlite to improve drainage.
fertilizer_details: Feed every 3 months with succulent fertilizer. Not heavy feeders.
toxicity: Toxic to pets. Can cause vomiting and depression.
propagation_details: Let cuttings dry 2-3 days before planting. Very easy to propagate.
common_problems: Soft leaves (overwatering), leaf drop (underwatering), stretched growth (needs more light)
pruning: Prune for shape in spring. Can be trained as bonsai
special_features: Symbol of good luck, can live 100+ years, develops thick trunk with age
trivia: In Feng Shui, jade plants near the entrance attract wealth and prosperity.
